page.title: 16Ecology in rural Sowerby
page.content: The situation between the Pennines to the West and the North Yorkshire Moors to the East has resulted in a milder climate than further north or southdue to the sheltered position. There is a small river flowing north to south in which there is fishing. There are two becks flowing into the river which act as a main drain. Kingfishers and herons can be seen along the river and there is a footpath along part of the river and two other main footpaths cross the area. Hedges are sometimes absent which means that part of the natural habitate for plants, insects, birds and small animals is absent. The area is very flat and can suffer from stronger winds than average. Most of the area is taken over by farming and not many trees.
